In successful preparations, however, there is not 
the slightest difficulty in making them out as they 
give to this part of the white matter a peculiar 
translucency. The best means of demonstrating them,
however, is simply in gross perpendicular segments 
of brain when hardened by my method. If such 
a brain be cut into large slices half-an-inch
thick & examined simply with the naked eye 
or with a pocket lens, they can be seen so
distinctly that I am surprised that they have 
not been recognized before. I have looked through 
the illustrations of sections of the brain given in 
the works of Foville, Gratiolet, Reichert, Bourgery, &
Arnold & three of more recent writers, but in none of them can I find these
fibres represented. In the fresh brain they are 
almost invisible; in one hardened in spirit 
they are a little better marked; but in a brain 
injected with the mixture of Muller’s fluid &
spirit that I have recommended they are 
perfectly distinctly observed <s>visible marked <s>. Their locality & course 
are brought much better into view when the 
surface is rendered quite flat by being planed 
in a freezing microtome such as I possess.
Viewed after these procedures they present the appear-
ance of a curved fibrous mass whose outer edge is 
perfectly differentiated and approaches close to 
the grey matter of the frontal cortex & while throughout the 
greater part of their course internally they
<s>internally <\s> sweep round <s>intern <\s>
the basal ganglia. They are represented in Figures 3, 4, 5, & 6.
